title: 108_hr5154
content: The Act may be cited as the "Uniformed Services Differential Pay Protection Act" and addresses income tax withholding on differential wage payments. The "Uniformed Services Differential Pay Protection Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat any differential wage payment to active duty members of the Uniformed Services as wages by the employer to the employee. Differential wage payment is defined as a payment made during active duty for more than 30 days. The amendment applies to remuneration paid after December 31, 2004, representing wages the individual would have received from the employer during service. The amendment applies to differential wage payments for retirement plan purposes paid after December 31, 2004. The amendment to Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 addresses the treatment of differential wage payments in retirement plans. It states that individuals receiving such payments are considered employees of the employer making the payment, the payment is treated as compensation, and the plan is not affected. This amendment applies to payments made after December 31, 2004. The amendment to Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 clarifies that differential wage payments in retirement plans are not considered a failure to meet plan requirements. It also specifies that individuals in uniformed services are treated as severed from employment for certain purposes. The amendment to Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 clarifies that differential wage payments in retirement plans are not considered a failure to meet plan requirements. It also specifies that individuals in uniformed services are treated as severed from employment for certain purposes, including limitations on elective deferrals and employee contributions during a 6-month period after receiving a distribution. Nondiscrimination requirements apply to all employees entitled to receive such payments.
